topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack 1.1: Enabling VLAN Provider Network in HPE Helion OpenStack

body.p: This page provides a detailed description to enable VLAN Provider Network in KVM Cloud Type.

HPE Helion OpenStack defaults to VxLAN to support tenant network isolation in a KVM Cloud Type. The deployment of HPE Helion OpenStack enables tenant's virtual machines hosted in a legacy infrastructure and/or based on VMWare ESX to communicate to a virtual machine running in HPE Helion OpenStack

section.title: Install Steps
section.p: This section describes the solution to set up the Overcloud Neutron Network to provide tenant network isolation by means of VLAN, instead of the default VxLAN.
The following prerequisites should be fulfilled to setup the Overcloud Neutron in VLAN:

li.p: Pass the right configuration parameters to the installer and templates for setting up the neutron configuration files:
/etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini- provides the VLAN ranges and bridge mappings to the physical bridge.
/etc/neutron/dhcp-agent.ini- enables Metadata Server access through DHCP Namespace.
Pass the right export variables pertinent to the VLAN Provider Network.

section.title: Verifying the installation

li.p: Log into the Horizon dashboard and create two projects (Tenant A and Tenant B) and also the users for these projects.
Run the neutron command as administrator.
Check that the default networks (default-net and ext-net) created during installation exist by entering:

codeblock.codeph: neutron net-show default-net neutron net-show ext-net

li.p: If these two networks exist, they have consumed VLAN IDs 300 and 301. Delete these two networks as you do not need them by entering:
li.codeblock: neutron delete default-net neutron delete ext-net

li.p: As administrator, create two Provider networks by entering:
li.codeblock:
neutron net-create --provider:physical_network=physnet1 --provider:network_type=vlan --provider:segmentation_id=300 vlan300 neutron subnet-create vlan300 192.168.100.0/24 -gateway 192.168.100.1
neutron net-create --provider:physical_network=physnet1 --provider:network_type=vlan --provider:segmentation_id=301 vlan301 neutron subnet-create vlan301 192.168.101.0/24 -gateway 192.168.101.1

li.p: Launch two instances in the vlan300 network and two in the vlan301 network.
Validate that the VMs in the same network are able to ping one another but unable to ping other instances in the other network.
Validate if you can ping the VMs from the KVM host.
Delete the four instances created by entering:
As administrator, remove the two provider VLAN networks by entering:
li.codeblock: neutron net-delete vlan300 neutron net-delete vlan301

section.note: As administrator, you can create a VLAN network outside of your defined VLAN by entering: neutron net-create --provider:physical_network=physnet1 --provider:network_type=vlan --provider:segmentation_id=900 vlan900

By default, Helion OpenStack 1.01, 1.1, and 1.1.1 Helion OpenStack creates a default-net and ext-net which take the first two VLAN IDs from your defined VLAN range. If you only define two VLANs for your HPE Helion OpenStack installation, you will not be able to create your provider network because default-net and ext-net have already consumed these two VLAN IDs. This is why you must first delete the default-net and ext-net to release the two VLAN IDs so you can create your provider network.
